titleStmt.title: Venetus A Main Scholia (Excerpt, Book 24, 311v. English

publicationStmt.p: Unpublished edition of the Venetus A manuscript for the Homer Multitext project

sourceDesc.p: Edited directly from photography of the manuscript

div.p:
[From this phrase] until [the line beginning] “τῶν μιμνησκόμενος” the lines are athetized because they are cheap (εὐτελής). And with them lifted out, the grief of Achilles is made clear more emphatically:
But he turned this way and that
At times on his back…
And “ἀνδροτῆτα” and “μένος” indicate the same thing, for there is no difference, and [Homer] never uses “ἀνδροτῆτα” for “άνδρείαν”, instead he uses “ἡνορέαν”. And “remembering these things” is awkward, because he has said “remembering his companion” above. And Aristphanes athetized these lines earlier. If you don't want to athetize the lines, then either the verb (ποθέων) should qualify everything (the main verbs ἐστρέφετ' (5) and εἶβεν (9) or there needs to be explicit punctuation after τὸ κύματα πείρων.⁑
